content.description: Tricky balance moves up a sharp arete gain a rail that you wish was better as you press out a tough mantel to finish.
content.location: The northeast arete of the boulder.

content.description: In your face stemming up a concavity with small edges and crystals for your hands. The technical and precise movements required for success will surely frustrate those accustomed to pulling on holds.
content.location: Just left of center on the east face.

content.description:
Balance and lieback up the grainy right-curving arete to an easy mantle/rockover at the top. Grainy but it'll clean up with more traffic.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.protection: pad, spotter to keep you of a rock near the base.
content.location:
The southwest arete of the boulder and 10' left of the

Sawzall Arete

.

content.description:
Romp up the scooped out face to arete using a series of dishes to an easy mantle at the top.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the east face and just left of the

Woody Problem

.

content.description:
Lieback and palm your way up the grainy left-curving arete to a crux mantle over the rounded top. Grainy but it'll clean up with more traffic.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Southeast arete of the boulder and just around the corner from

Sportin' Wood

.
